INDICATOR.title: Humor
INDICATOR.description: Exceptionally keen sense of the comical, the bizarre, or absurd.

INDICATOR.title: Imagination and creativity
INDICATOR.description: Extraordinary ability to use ideas, processes, materials or anything else in ingenious, flexible or surprising ways.

INDICATOR.title: Inquiry
INDICATOR.description: Probes deeply while exploring ideas & topics; asks deep questions; experiments with events, ideas, feelings, sounds, symbols, movement, etc.

INDICATOR.title: Memory and processing
INDICATOR.description: Tremendous capacity for dealing with large amounts of information and skills

INDICATOR.title: Sensitivity
INDICATOR.description: Unusually aware of or responsive to her/his own experiences and feelings and/or those of others.

INDICATOR.title: Expressiveness
INDICATOR.description: Extraordinary ability to communicate meaning or emotion through words, actions, symbols, sounds, or media.

INDICATOR.title: Reasoning
INDICATOR.description: Loves to think; thinks things through, considers implications or alternatives; rich, flexible, highly conscious, analytical or logical thought. Thinking is not necessarily directed toward a goal or solution.

INDICATOR.title: Problem-solving
INDICATOR.description: Outstanding ability to find systematic solutions to problems; is able to invent and monitor many paths to a goal; seeks out challenging problems.

INDICATOR.title: Intuition
INDICATOR.description: Suddenly discovers connections or deeper meanings without conscious awareness of reasoning or thought.

INDICATOR.title: Learning
INDICATOR.description: Extremely able to grasp and use sophisticated new understandings quickly and easily.

INDICATOR.title: Interests
INDICATOR.description: Advanced, intensely focused curiousity; passionate; may focus on unusual topics; interest is sometimes fleeting but always intense.

INDICATOR.title: Moral and ethical concerns
INDICATOR.description: Extreme need for fairness and justice; will take action to resolve injustices; deeply concerned with the consequences of her or his actions.

INDICATOR.title: Motivation
INDICATOR.description: Persistent, intense need to know, do, feel, create, or understand.

DIFFOPT.title: Abstractness
DIFFOPT.description: The content focuses on abstract concepts, themes, generalizations and theories, not concrete facts. It addresses ideas that have a wide range of applicability.

DIFFOPT.title: Complexity
DIFFOPT.description: Complex content focuses on the interconnections among concepts, principles, generalizations and theories. It is usually interdisciplinary.

DIFFOPT.title: Extracurricular Topics
DIFFOPT.description: The content includes ideas and content areas not taught in the regular curriculum in any grade. It may include the student's interests.

DIFFOPT.title: Lives and Living
DIFFOPT.description: The content involves the study of creative, productive people (living or dead), their motivations, social characteristics, challenges and career paths.

DIFFOPT.title: Organization for learning value
DIFFOPT.description: The content of an entire unit addresses a broad, interdisciplinary theme (like "systems" or "patterns") rather than small, sequential bits of information.

DIFFOPT.title: Real Life Topics
DIFFOPT.description: The content addresses issues, controversies, problems or provocative questions inspired by students' interests, experiences, questions and concerns. Students may need help focusing, analyzing, and/or defining their topic or questions.

DIFFOPT.title: Self-Selected Content
DIFFOPT.description: The student chooses the content. Some will need help choosing and reducing their interests to topics that are manageable.

DIFFOPT.title: Complex Thinking
DIFFOPT.description: Emphasize learning processes (verbs) that stress the use, rather than the acquisition of information (higher level thinking, critical thinking, creative thinking, etc.).

DIFFOPT.title: Expert Methods
DIFFOPT.description: Learning with and about methods used by experts in a discipline.

DIFFOPT.title: Group Interaction
DIFFOPT.description: Students collaborate with peers who have similar abilities and share their passions in order to enhance their social and leadership skills, learn perspective-taking and become more empathetic.

DIFFOPT.title: Individual Pursuits
DIFFOPT.description: Individual projects on which students work relatively independently but with the support of a teacher or mentor available as needed.

DIFFOPT.title: Inquiry-based learning
DIFFOPT.description: Inductive reasoning processes are used to discover patterns, underlying principles and generalizations. Students take greater responsibility for their learning than in deductive learning experiences.

DIFFOPT.title: Open-endedness
DIFFOPT.description: Activities involve open-ended questions, activities, projects and methods. These have no predetermined correct outcome. They are provocative, stimulating students to think broadly.

DIFFOPT.title: Pacing
DIFFOPT.description: Students learn at a pace commensurate with their ability to go quickly through or deeply into content. Examples include pretesting, "compacting", or "telescoping" curriculum, or other forms of acceleration.

DIFFOPT.title: Reasoning and Reflection
DIFFOPT.description: Students explain their conclusions and the reasoning that led to them as well as the metacognitive aspect of their thinking. They are encouraged to evaluate both the process and products of their own and others' thinking.

DIFFOPT.title: Self-selected Process
DIFFOPT.description: Students choose the ways they will learn. Some may need assistance identifying their preferences or following through on their choices.

DIFFOPT.title: Variety
DIFFOPT.description: A range of methods of thinking and feeling involved in learning by using different types of problems, resources and technologies.

DIFFOPT.title: Authentic Audiences
DIFFOPT.description: Results of the learning activity should be shared with real and appropriate audiences to the greatest extent possible. This may involve the scientific community, the city council, a government agency, art critic, etc.

DIFFOPT.title: Feedback and Assessment
DIFFOPT.description: Products should be assessed using real, predetermined procedures and criteria, and as often as possible, by a member or members of the real audience for the product. Students should also be encouraged or required to self-evaluate their products using the same criteria.

DIFFOPT.title: Self-selected Product
DIFFOPT.description: The student chooses an appropriate format for the product that reflects what was learned. Students' interests, strengths and prior experiences may influence these choices. Teachers may need to provide assistance in the selection and development of the product.

DIFFOPT.title: Transformations
DIFFOPT.description: The results of the learning process should represent a "conversion of known information into new entities - changes in meaning, significance, use, interpretation, mood, sensory qualities,or shape" (Guilford, 1967).

DIFFOPT.title: Variety
DIFFOPT.description: Students learn about and use different types of production techniques and media throughout the school year or term. They should also learn to select an appropriate format for the audience and content.
